questions.text: A 76-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of an episode of seeing jagged edges followed by loss of central vision in his right eye. The episode occurred 6 hours ago and lasted approximately 5 minutes. The patient has no pain. He has a 3-month history of intermittent blurriness out of his right eye and reports a 10-minute episode of slurred speech and left-sided facial droop that occurred 2 months ago. He has hypercholesterolemia, stable angina pectoris, hypertension, and a 5-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. Medications include glyburide, atorvastatin, labetalol, isosorbide, lisinopril, and aspirin. He feels well. He is oriented to person, place, and time. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 154/78 mm Hg. The extremities are well perfused with strong peripheral pulses. Ophthalmologic examination shows visual acuity of 20/30 in the left eye and 20/40 in the right eye. Visual fields are normal. Fundoscopic examination shows two grayish-white spots along the supratemporal and inferotemporal arcade. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Cardiopulmonary examination shows systolic rumbling at the right carotid artery. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An ECG shows normal sinus rhythm with no evidence of ischemia. In addition to obtaining a CT scan of the head, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Echocardiography is used to evaluate for cardiac causes of retinal vessel occlusion and TIA, such as emboli due to atrial fibrillation. Cardiogenic emboli are the most common cause of retinal artery occlusion in younger patients (< 40 years of age) and should be suspected based on a patient history that includes, e.g., atrial fibrillation (AF), endocarditis, or valvular disease. However, while this patient does have a history and exam findings that both suggest retinal vessel occlusion and a TIA, he has no AF and there are signs of carotid artery stenosis. Echocardiography would be an appropriate step in management only after atherosclerotic causes of this patient's symptoms have been ruled out.

B) INCORRECT:

Fluorescein angiography allows for visualization of flow through the retinal vessels and may be used to diagnose a variety of retinal disorders, such as macular degeneration, diabetic retinopathy, and retinal vascular occlusions. While fluorescein angiography might show slow or absent filling of retinal arteries in retinal artery occlusion, it is usually indicated when the diagnosis is not otherwise clear, e.g., when ischemic retinal whitening is not clearly present on fundoscopy. In this case, such findings are apparent, as is the diagnosis of retinal artery occlusion. Fluorescein angiography would not contribute significantly to this patient's care.

C) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and follow-up might be appropriate in a patient with transient vision loss secondary to a benign etiology. For example, migraine is the most common cause of transient binocular vision loss in young adults. This patient's vision loss was transient and he has a history of intermittent blurriness that could be consistent with migrainous aura, but the lack of other migraine symptoms, along with the monocular presentation, make the diagnosis of migrainous aura unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Temporal artery biopsy could conclusively evaluate for the presence of giant cell arteritis (GCA), which can result in permanent vision loss if untreated. Suspicion of GCA should be especially high in patients above the age of 50 with fundoscopy findings of pallid optic disc swelling without apparent emboli. While our patient's monocular vision loss and history of intermittent monocular blurriness could be consistent with GCA, he lacks additional symptoms such as temporal headache or jaw claudication, and his fundus examination reveals clearly demarcated areas of vascular involvement, which is not consistent with GCA. A temporal artery biopsy is therefore not indicated.

E) CORRECT:

Carotid duplex ultrasonography is the best next step in the management of a patient with transient retinal artery occlusion secondary to atherosclerotic emboli. This procedure allows for the assessment of the carotid arteries for atherosclerotic plaques and vessel stenosis, and thus the patient's candidacy for treatment options (e.g., antiplatelet therapy, carotid endarterectomy).

Retinal vessel occlusion is primarily a clinical diagnosis, so confirmatory testing is generally not indicated, except in unusual cases. This patient presented with classic history and exam findings, making testing unnecessary in his case. Instead, the diagnostic focus is on the cause of occlusion, which might be cardiovascular or inflammatory disease.
questions.hint: Sudden, painless, transient monocular loss of vision with cloudy discoloration along the retinal arterial supply on fundoscopy is highly suggestive of retinal artery occlusion. The most common cause in older adults is atherosclerotic emboli, which is consistent with this patient's age, extensive atherosclerotic risk factors (hypercholesterolemia, stable angina pectoris, hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus), history of possible transient ischemic attack, and finding of an ipsilateral carotid bruit on examination.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of sudden, painless loss of vision in her right eye that occurred 30 minutes ago while watching TV. She has coronary artery disease, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus, and has had trouble adhering to her medication regimen. Her blood pressure is 160/85 mm Hg. Examination shows 20/50 vision in the left eye and no perception of light in the right eye. Direct pupillary reflex is present in the left eye but absent in the right eye. Accommodation is intact bilaterally. Intraocular pressure is 16 mm Hg in the left eye and 18 mm Hg in the right eye. Fundoscopic examination of the right eye shows a pale, white retina with a bright red area within the macula. The optic disc appears normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypertension, diabetes, and atherosclerosis are all risk factors for ischemic central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO). It may manifest with sudden, painless loss of vision and a relative afferent pupillary defect as well as severe edema of the macula and optic disc. However, fundoscopy would reveal focal retinal hemorrhage instead of a white, pale retina. The most common form of CRVO is nonischemic and results in a decrease in visual acuity over the course of a few days instead of sudden loss of vision seen here.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of a right eye

Multiple punctual hemorrhages in every quadrant of the retina and flame-shaped hemorrhages in the peripapillary and perivascular region are present (examples marked by blue overlay), as are markedly dilated tortuous veins (example framed by white lines) and mild disk edema (blurry margin of the disc marked by dashed blue line, sharply demarcated margin marked by blue line).

This is the classic appearance of central retinal vein occlusion.

M: Macula

B) INCORRECT:

Both hypertension and diabetes mellitus are risk factors for retinal detachment. Patients with extensive retinal detachment or retinal detachment involving the macula would also present with sudden, painless loss of vision, and an afferent pupillary defect. However, fundoscopy would reveal a gray, detached, freely floating retina. Retinal pallor and a cherry red spot within the macula suggest a different diagnosis.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of the left eye

Fibrovascular proliferation (green overlay) obscures the optic disc (dashed circle) and can be seen extending along the retinal vasculature in fibrovascular strands. This has resulted in tractional retinal detachment (blue overlay). Multiple retinal hemorrhages can also be seen (arrowheads).

These findings are characteristic of severe proliferative diabetic retinopathy.

M: macula; N: nasal; T: temporal

C) CORRECT:

The patient has multiple risk factors for retinal artery disease, including diabetes, hypertension, and atherosclerosis. Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) is characterized by sudden, painless loss of vision and an afferent pupillary defect. Ophthalmoscopy findings of CRAO include retinal pallor and a cherry-red spot in the foveal region. Narrow retinal vessels with a cattle-truck appearance are another classic finding of retinal artery occlusion.

Retinal artery occlusion is an ophthalmologic emergency.
Image Description:

Left: lateral view of the right eye in longitudinal (sagittal) section. Depiction of an embolism in the central retinal artery causing retinal ischemia.

Right: fundus photography of the right eye. Diffuse retinal ischemia causes edema in the inner retinal layers, manifesting as a gray-white discoloration of the retina (most markedly around the fovea; dotted circle). The fovea centralis, where the inner retinal layers are moved to the side, is not affected by edema. The underlying, well-vascularized choroid shines through, appearing as a cherry-red spot.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with acute angle closure glaucoma may present with sudden loss of vision, and an absent or sluggish direct pupillary reflex. However, the loss of vision in the case of acute angle closure glaucoma is always associated with severe pain and increased intraocular pressure (> 21 mm Hg), as opposed to the normal intraocular pressure in this patient (18 mm Hg in the right eye). The indirect pupillary reflex and the accommodation reflex, which are normal in this patient, would also be impaired. Injection and chemosis of the conjunctiva, as well as trigeminal autonomic symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and lacrimation, which are frequently present in acute angle closure glaucoma, are absent in this patient. On fundoscopy, the optic disc would appear edematous or hyperemic, in contrast to the normal optic disc in this patient.
Image Description:

Slit-lamp photograph of anterior eye segment

Prominent blood vessels are visible on the sclera and conjunctiva (mixed injection). The pupil is medium wide and its shape is slightly irregular. Iris details appear blurred due to corneal endothelial decompensation, leading to corneal edema.

E) INCORRECT:

Anterior ischemic optic neuropathy may also present with sudden, painless loss of vision. However, fundoscopy would reveal a hyperemic or edematous optic disc and possibly splinter hemorrhages within the optic disc, as opposed to a normal optic disc seen in this patient. Retinal pallor and a cherry red spot within the macula suggest a different diagnosis.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of a right eye

The optic disc (dashed circle) shows blurred margins and radial bleedings (arrowheads). The retinal veins are dilated and tortuous (examples indicated by white lines). In addition, the macula (M) shows pigment alterations (blue overlay).

This is the typical appearance of papilledema, in this case caused by NAION. Papilledema can also be caused by arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AAION), inflammatory processes, or elevated intracranial pressure.

Hatched overlay: artifacts
questions.hint: Indirect pupillary reflex will likely be absent in the left (not right!) eye, which would be consistent with retinal or optic nerve damage.

questions.text: An 81-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of left-sided visual loss that started 1 hour ago. He describes initially seeing jagged edges, which was followed by abrupt, complete loss of central vision in the left eye. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Blood pressure is 145/89 mm Hg. Neurologic examination shows no abnormalities. A photograph of the fundoscopic findings is shown. Which of the following tests is most likely to confirm this patient's underlying condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased glycated hemoglobin concentrations are seen in patients with poorly controlled diabetes mellitus. This patient has a history of diabetes and is therefore at risk of diabetic retinopathy, a condition that can cause visual impairment and blindness. However, vision loss in diabetic retinopathy is typically bilateral and occurs over the course of many years, as opposed to the abrupt, unilateral vision loss seen in this patient. Direct fundoscopy in a patient with diabetic retinopathy shows microaneurysms, hard exudates, and macular edema (nonproliferative) or retinal neovascularization and vitreous hemorrhage (proliferative).

B) CORRECT:

Carotid artery duplex ultrasonography can be used to evaluate for carotid atherosclerosis, a condition that increases the risk of thromboembolism due to rupture of atherosclerotic plaques, which is the most common cause of central retinal artery occlusion. This patient has several atherosclerotic risk factors, including advanced age, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus, which make thromboembolism secondary to carotid artery atherosclerosis the most likely cause of his symptoms.
Image Description:

Left: lateral view of the right eye in longitudinal (sagittal) section. Depiction of an embolism in the central retinal artery causing retinal ischemia.

Right: fundus photography of the right eye. Diffuse retinal ischemia causes edema in the inner retinal layers, manifesting as a gray-white discoloration of the retina (most markedly around the fovea; dotted circle). The fovea centralis, where the inner retinal layers are moved to the side, is not affected by edema. The underlying, well-vascularized choroid shines through, appearing as a cherry-red spot.

C) INCORRECT:

Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) is a nonspecific inflammatory marker that can be increased in cases of infection, inflammation, or malignancy. Temporal arteritis can cause significant elevation in ESR and is a rare etiology of central retinal artery occlusion, the most likely diagnosis in this patient. However, he lacks other symptoms of temporal arteritis (e.g., headache, jaw claudication, constitutional symptoms). Moreover, a temporal artery biopsy, not ESR, is the gold standard for the diagnosis of temporal arteritis.

D) INCORRECT:

A CD4+ T cell count can be used to track the prognosis in patients diagnosed with or suspected of having HIV. Patients with a low CD4 count are more susceptible to cytomegalovirus, which can cause retinitis and vision loss. However, CMV retinitis causes progressive loss of vision over days as opposed to the abrupt onset seen in this patient's case. Direct fundoscopy in a patient with CMV retinitis shows retinal hemorrhages and cotton wool spots.

E) INCORRECT:

An optic tonometer is used to measure intraocular pressure (IOP). Increased IOP is seen in patients with glaucoma and patients with increased intracranial pressure (ICP). Both of these conditions can lead to visual impairment. In particular, acute, closed-angle glaucoma can cause sudden-onset visual loss. However, it is typically painful and associated with headache and vomiting, none of which is seen in this patient. Direct fundoscopy in patients with increased ICP shows papilledema.
questions.hint: The fundoscopy shows a pale retina with a cherry red spot at the fovea. Together with sudden, painless, transient monocular vision, this finding is concerning for central retinal artery occlusion. Causes include embolism (most common), thrombosis, vasculitis, and fibromuscular dysplasia.

questions.text: An 82-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-hour history of decreased vision in his right eye. He has no pain in the eye and has never had a similar episode in the past. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and open-angle glaucoma. He does not smoke and occasionally drinks 1–2 glasses of wine. Current medications include metformin, glipizide, lisinopril, and topical latanoprost. His temperature is 36.6°C (97.9°F), pulse is 68/min and regular, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 135/82 mm Hg. Ophthalmologic examination shows visual acuity of 20/200 in the right eye and 20/60 in the left eye. The direct pupillary reflex is brisk in the left eye but absent in the right eye. Applanation tonometry shows an intraocular pressure of 20 mm Hg in the right eye and 18 mm Hg in the left eye (N = 10–21). Fundoscopy of the right eye shows the findings in the photograph. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Topical pilocarpine and systemic acetazolamide therapy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous thrombolysis may be considered in the management of central retinal artery occlusion. This condition manifests with sudden, painless loss of vision and an afferent pupillary defect in one eye. However, fundoscopy typically shows a cherry-red spot at the fovea centralis against a grayish-white discoloration of the entire retina, as well as retinal plaques/emboli (i.e., cholesterol emboli, platelet thrombi, calcific plaques).
Image Description:

Left: lateral view of the right eye in longitudinal (sagittal) section. Depiction of an embolism in the central retinal artery causing retinal ischemia.

Right: fundus photography of the right eye. Diffuse retinal ischemia causes edema in the inner retinal layers, manifesting as a gray-white discoloration of the retina (most markedly around the fovea; dotted circle). The fovea centralis, where the inner retinal layers are moved to the side, is not affected by edema. The underlying, well-vascularized choroid shines through, appearing as a cherry-red spot.

B) INCORRECT:

Emergency retinal tamponade is the treatment of choice for rhegmatogenous retinal detachment. This type of retinal detachment can manifest with sudden, painless loss of vision and an afferent pupillary defect in one eye. However, this condition is often preceded by prodromal symptoms that result from posterior vitreous detachment, including floaters, photopsia, and scotomas. Moreover, ophthalmoscopy typically shows a detached gray retina that floats freely in the vitreous body and has a blood-vessel orientation different from the normal retina; a deeply red retinal tear may also be visible.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of the eye

In the upper part of the image, the retina is visible as a yellow-gray, bullous elevation (green overlay). This part of the retina is detached due to a retinal tear (red overlay).

C) INCORRECT:

Topical pilocarpine and systemic acetazolamide are indicated for treating acute angle-closure glaucoma, which is common in older adults and causes sudden-onset, unilaterally blurry vision, decreased visual acuity, and a nonreactive pupil, similar to what is seen here. However, this condition typically manifests with a reddened and severely painful eye that is hard on palpation, a cloudy cornea, headache, as well as nausea and vomiting. In contrast, this patient has a normal intraocular pressure on tonometry.
Image Description:

Slit-lamp photograph of anterior eye segment

Prominent blood vessels are visible on the sclera and conjunctiva (mixed injection). The pupil is medium wide and its shape is slightly irregular. Iris details appear blurred due to corneal endothelial decompensation, leading to corneal edema.

D) CORRECT:

Fluorescein angiography (FA) is indicated as the next step to confirm the diagnosis of CRVO, evaluate the severity of CRVO, and decide whether laser photocoagulation should be performed. Retinal nonperfusion predisposes to complications of neovascularization (i.e., rubeosis iridis, neovascular glaucoma, vitreous hemorrhage, retinal detachment). To prevent neovascularization, CRVO must be treated with panretinal photocoagulation and intravitreal injection of VEGF inhibitors and/or steroids. Further work-up includes optical coherence tomography, which helps to determine the extent of macular edema and monitor the response to treatment. CRVO has a poor prognosis: visual acuity only improves in a third of patients.
Image Description:

Fluorescein angiography of the right eye

There is hypoperfusion of the temporal inferior vascular arcade, with capillary nonperfusion visible as areas of hypofluorescence (blue overlay). Vessels are tortuous. There is no neovascularization.

This is the typical appearance of ischemic RVO on fluorescein angiography.

Blue circle: Optic disc
M: Macula

E) INCORRECT:

MRI of the head is indicated for patients with optic neuritis. This condition manifests with sudden-onset unilateral vision loss and an afferent pupillary defect. However, optic neuritis is usually seen in adults under 50 years of age and manifests with retrobulbar pain that increases with eye movements, which is not reported in this patient. Most affected individuals have multiple sclerosis; other common etiologies include infections (e.g., tuberculosis, Lyme disease) and use of toxic substances (e.g., ethambutol, methanol). Moreover, loss of color vision and visual field defects (e.g., central scotoma) are common features, and ophthalmoscopy findings may be normal (in retrobulbar neuritis) or show signs of papillitis. This patient, in contrast, has classic findings of CRVO on fundoscopy.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of the left eye of a patient with acute vision loss and painful eye movements

Discrete optic disc edema is visible: Discrete blurring of the nasal superior, superior, and temporal superior disc margin can be seen (green overlay). Otherwise, the fundus is normal.

This finding, in addition to the patient's symptoms, suggests papillitis in optic neuritis.

M: macula; circle: optic disc
questions.hint: Fundoscopy shows flame-shaped hemorrhages in all four retinal quadrants (blood and thunder appearance), tortuous dilated veins, papilledema, and cotton wool spots. In conjunction with sudden painless loss of vision and an afferent pupillary defect, these findings suggest central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO). Risk factors for this condition include older age, diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and glaucoma.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man comes to the emergency department 45 minutes after a sudden transient loss of vision in his right eye. The vision loss was painless and lasted for 5 minutes. He had no other symptoms and says he has never had a similar episode before. He has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 48 years and drinks one beer daily. Current medications include enalapril, atorvastatin, and metformin. He is 167 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 89 kg (196 lb); BMI is 32 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 72/min and regular, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 148/91 mm Hg. Visual acuity is 20/32 bilaterally. Intraocular pressure is 15 mm Hg in the right eye and 16 mm Hg in the left eye (N = 10–21). The pupil is reactive and the cornea and anterior chamber are clear. Fundoscopic examination of the right eye shows a few microaneurysms, increased tortuosity of the retinal arterioles, and bright yellow, refractile bodies at the bifurcations of the retinal arterioles. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 15 mm/h. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's loss of vision?

choices.text: Granulomatous inflammation of the ophthalmic artery
Stenosis of the internal carotid artery
Immune-mediated demyelination of the optic nerve
Thrombotic occlusion of the retinal vein
Stasis of blood in the atrium

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dry age-related macular degeneration (AMD) causes the formation of drusen, which are yellow retinal spots that can have a refractile appearance. However, these spots would be clustered around the macula rather than the bifurcations of the retinal arterioles and dry AMD does not cause acute visual impairment.

Wet AMD can lead to subretinal hemorrhage, manifesting with acute monocular visual impairment. This patient does not have subretinal hemorrhage or any other signs of wet AMD (e.g., gray-green retinal discoloration, serous detachment of the retina) on fundoscopic examination and contrary to this patient's presentation, visual impairment after subretinal hemorrhage resolves slowly over several weeks.

B) INCORRECT:

Granulomatous inflammation of the ophthalmic artery is seen in giant cell arteritis (GCA). This condition may cause anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION), which can manifest with monocular amaurosis fugax. However, patients with GCA usually have other symptoms as well (e.g., constitutional symptoms, jaw claudication, headache) and, most importantly, an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Furthermore, AION due to GCA typically manifests with papilledema on fundoscopic examination.

C) CORRECT:

Carotid artery stenosis (CAS) can manifest with monocular amaurosis fugax due to retinal ischemia, caused by stenosis-induced hypoperfusion, thrombosis, or microemboli. This patient has several risk factors for atherosclerosis (hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus, smoking), and fundoscopic examination revealed cholesterol crystal emboli, which most commonly originate from carotid artery atheromas.

Workup for patients with amaurosis fugax generally includes carotid duplex ultrasound to screen for CAS. Carotid revascularization is indicated for patients with symptomatic (e.g., those with amaurosis fugax), severe CAS, and should be considered for patients with symptomatic, moderate CAS, and asymptomatic patients with severe CAS.

D) INCORRECT:

Immune-mediated demyelination of the optic nerve (i.e., optic neuritis) typically manifests with monocular vision loss with a progressive onset over hours/days and a peak in impairment after 1–2 weeks, unlike this patient's presentation with amaurosis fugax. Patients with optic neuritis develop papilledema (in the case of papillitis) or have normal fundoscopic findings (in the case of retrobulbar neuritis).
Image Description:

Fundus photography of the left eye of a patient with acute vision loss and painful eye movements

Discrete optic disc edema is visible: Discrete blurring of the nasal superior, superior, and temporal superior disc margin can be seen (green overlay). Otherwise, the fundus is normal.

This finding, in addition to the patient's symptoms, suggests papillitis in optic neuritis.

M: macula; circle: optic disc

E) INCORRECT:

Thrombotic occlusion of the retinal vein (i.e., central retinal vein occlusion) typically leads to a sudden, monocular loss of vision. However, vision loss in central retinal vein occlusion usually does not resolve spontaneously. Furthermore, this condition manifests with massive retinal hemorrhages, dilated tortuous retinal veins, macular edema, and papilledema on fundoscopic examination, none of which is seen here.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of the right eye of a 76-year-old patient

Flame-shaped retinal hemorrhage is visible in all four quadrants (example indicated by green outline). The tortuous veins (green arrows) are markedly dilated and there is papilledema with loss of sharp demarcation of the optic disc (green overlay).

These findings are typical for a central retinal vein occlusion.

F) INCORRECT:

Stasis of blood in the atrium, which occurs in patients with atrial fibrillation (Afib), increases the risk of atrial thrombus formation and arterial thromboembolism. Transient embolic occlusion of the central retinal artery would cause amaurosis fugax. However, this patient does not have an irregular pulse to suggest Afib, and thromboemboli, which are composed of platelets and fibrin, have a white-gray, pale, and nonrefractile appearance on fundoscopy.
questions.hint: This patient presents with painless, monocular amaurosis fugax (i.e., sudden transient vision loss). His fundoscopic examination shows Hollenhorst plaques (bright, yellow, refractile bodies at the bifurcations of the retinal arterioles), which are consistent with cholesterol crystal embolization. He also has signs of hypertensive retinopathy (e.g., microaneurysms, increased tortuosity of the retinal arterioles).

questions.text: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of sudden loss of vision in his right eye that occurred 1 hour ago. He does not have eye pain. He had several similar episodes of loss of vision; as these episodes all resolved after some minutes, he did not follow up on them. He has a history of hypertension, coronary artery disease, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His father died from myocardial infarction at the age of 70 years. He has smoked up to one pack of cigarettes daily for 43 years and drinks one alcoholic beverage 3–5 days per week. Current medications include aspirin, nitroglycerin, lisinopril, metoprolol, atorvastatin, and metformin. His temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 148/84 mm Hg. Ophthalmologic examination shows no perception of light in the right eye and 20/40 vision in the left eye. Corneal reflexes are brisk. The swinging flashlight test shows dilation of both pupils when the right eye is illuminated. Intraocular pressure is 17 mm Hg in the right eye and 16 mm Hg in the left eye. Examination of the lids and conjunctiva shows no abnormalities. Neurologic examination shows no other focal findings. On auscultation, there is a bruit over the right carotid artery. Fundoscopy of the right eye shows the findings in the photograph. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Optic neuritis (ON) may manifest with a sudden loss of vision and an afferent pupillary defect, both of which are seen here. ON is most commonly caused by multiple sclerosis (MS), and this patient's history of recurring loss of vision could be consistent with the relapsing course of MS. However, fundoscopy is typically unremarkable in ON; the findings seen in this patient would not be expected.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of the left eye of a patient with acute vision loss and painful eye movements

Discrete optic disc edema is visible: Discrete blurring of the nasal superior, superior, and temporal superior disc margin can be seen (green overlay). Otherwise, the fundus is normal.

This finding, in addition to the patient's symptoms, suggests papillitis in optic neuritis.

M: macula; circle: optic disc

B) INCORRECT:

Ischemic central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) manifests with sudden, painless loss of vision and a relative afferent pupillary defect. Furthermore, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and atherosclerosis are risk factors for CRVO. However, in ischemic CRVO, fundoscopy would reveal multiple foci of retinal hemorrhage as well as severe edema of the macula and optic disc, neither of which is consistent with the findings seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of the right eye of a 76-year-old patient

Flame-shaped retinal hemorrhage is visible in all four quadrants (example indicated by green outline). The tortuous veins (green arrows) are markedly dilated and there is papilledema with loss of sharp demarcation of the optic disc (green overlay).

These findings are typical for a central retinal vein occlusion.

C) CORRECT:

Central retinal artery occlusion is characterized by sudden, painless loss of vision and a relative afferent pupillary defect, which manifests with no perception of light in the affected eye and an abnormal swinging flashlight test. A past history of amaurosis fugax is also common. This patient has multiple risk factors for retinal artery disease, including diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and atherosclerosis. Along with the multiple cardiovascular risk factors, a carotid bruit suggests carotid artery atherosclerosis, which can lead to the release of a thrombus and subsequent occlusion of the central retinal artery; this is the most common cause of central retinal artery occlusion.

Retinal artery occlusion is an ophthalmologic emergency.
Image Description:

Left: lateral view of the right eye in longitudinal (sagittal) section. Depiction of an embolism in the central retinal artery causing retinal ischemia.

Right: fundus photography of the right eye. Diffuse retinal ischemia causes edema in the inner retinal layers, manifesting as a gray-white discoloration of the retina (most markedly around the fovea; dotted circle). The fovea centralis, where the inner retinal layers are moved to the side, is not affected by edema. The underlying, well-vascularized choroid shines through, appearing as a cherry-red spot.

D) INCORRECT:

Acute angle-closure glaucoma (AACG) can manifest with a sudden loss of vision and a relative afferent pupillary defect, both of which are seen here. However, the loss of vision is always painful and patients have an increased intraocular pressure (> 21 mm Hg), as opposed to the normal intraocular pressure in this patient. Furthermore, patients with AACG often present with injection and chemosis of the conjunctiva as well as trigeminal autonomic symptoms (e.g., nausea, vomiting, lacrimation). On fundoscopy, the optic disc would appear edematous or hyperemic, in contrast to the normal optic disc in this patient.
Image Description:

Slit-lamp photograph of anterior eye segment

Prominent blood vessels are visible on the sclera and conjunctiva (mixed injection). The pupil is medium wide and its shape is slightly irregular. Iris details appear blurred due to corneal endothelial decompensation, leading to corneal edema.

E) INCORRECT:

Anterior ischemic optic neuropathy can manifest with sudden, painless loss of vision, which this patient has. However, fundoscopy would show a hyperemic or edematous optic disc and possibly splinter hemorrhages within the optic disc, as opposed to the normal optic disc seen in this patient. Retinal and macular changes, which are seen here, would not be expected in anterior ischemic optic neuropathy.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of a right eye

The optic disc (dashed circle) shows blurred margins and radial bleedings (arrowheads). The retinal veins are dilated and tortuous (examples indicated by white lines). In addition, the macula (M) shows pigment alterations (blue overlay).

This is the typical appearance of papilledema, in this case caused by NAION. Papilledema can also be caused by arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AAION), inflammatory processes, or elevated intracranial pressure.

Hatched overlay: artifacts

F) INCORRECT:

Massive vitreous hemorrhage can manifest with sudden, painless loss of vision and an afferent pupillary defect, both of which are seen here. Furthermore, both hypertension and diabetes mellitus, which this patient has, are risk factors for vitreous hemorrhage. However, the view of the retina on fundoscopy would be obscured by blood, and visualization of the optic disc and macula would not be possible, in contrast to this patient's clearly visible fundus.

G) INCORRECT:

Extensive retinal detachment or retinal detachment involving the macula can manifest with sudden, painless loss of vision and an afferent pupillary defect, both of which are seen here. Furthermore, both hypertension and diabetes mellitus, which this patient has, are risk factors for retinal detachment. However, fundoscopy would show a gray, detached, freely floating retina.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of the eye

In the upper part of the image, the retina is visible as a yellow-gray, bullous elevation (green overlay). This part of the retina is detached due to a retinal tear (red overlay).

H) INCORRECT:

Exudative (wet) age-related macular degeneration (AMD) can manifest with unilateral, acute, painless vision impairment. Furthermore, cardiovascular disease and smoking history, both present in this patient, are risk factors for AMD. However, AMD usually does not lead to a complete loss of vision, but rather manifests with central scotoma (a blind spot) and metamorphopsia. Moreover, fundoscopy in wet AMD would show gray-green retinal discoloration, subretinal or intraretinal hemorrhages, and macular edema.
questions.hint: Fundoscopy shows retinal pallor, a cherry-red spot in the foveal region, and box-carring of the retinal vessels. These findings suggest ischemia.

questions.text:
A 76-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 90-minute history of vision loss in his left eye that developed suddenly while he was watching television. He has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and poorly controlled type 2 diabetes. He has no eye pain, headache, or other symptoms. A dilated retinal examination is performed (figure).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Central retinal artery occlusion also causes sudden painless vision loss, but the typical retinal examination findings are different. The figure shows the typical findings of retinal whitening with a cherry-red spot in the fovea (arrow) due to the preserved underlying choroidal circulation. There is also constriction of the arteriole and venule with segmentation (arrowhead). Retinal hemorrhages are uncommon in this type of occlusion. Evaluation for an embolic source is appropriate in patients with central retinal artery occlusion.
Image Description:

The image shows the typical findings of retinal whitening with a cherry-red spot in the fovea (arrow) due to the preserved underlying choroidal circulation. There is also constriction of the arteriole and venule with segmentation (arrowhead).

B) CORRECT:

Acute vision loss in combination with a retinal examination showing diffuse retinal hemorrhages and dilated, tortuous veins is most consistent with a diagnosis of central retinal vein occlusion.

Risk factors for such occlusion include atherosclerosis, hypertension, glaucoma, and hypercoagulable states. Patients with central retinal vein occlusion should be followed closely for the development of complications associated with neovascularization, such as neovascular glaucoma.

Key learning point: Sudden painless unilateral vision loss and findings of diffuse retinal hemorrhages extending to the periphery and dilated, tortuous veins on retinal examination are indicative of central retinal vein occlusion.

C) INCORRECT:

Arteritic ischemic optic neuropathy from giant-cell arteritis can cause acute painless vision loss, but it only affects the optic nerve and does not cause diffuse retinal findings. It is often associated with headache, scalp tenderness, and jaw claudication.

D) INCORRECT:

Diabetes does not generally cause acute vision loss, except in cases of advanced proliferative diabetic retinopathy. Diabetes can be associated with retinal hemorrhages, but they are usually smaller “dot-blot” hemorrhages that are bilateral and localized to the posterior pole.

E) INCORRECT:

Macular degeneration is generally a slow progressive process and affects only the macula, not the entire retina.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man comes to the emergency department 45 minutes after a sudden transient loss of vision in his right eye. The vision loss was painless and lasted for 5 minutes. He has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 48 years. Pulse is 72/min and regular. Fundoscopic examination of the right eye shows Hollenhorst plaques. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 10 mm/h. ECG shows regular sinus rhythm. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's loss of vision?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dry age-related macular degeneration (AMD) causes the formation of drusen, which are yellow retinal spots that can have a refractile appearance. However, these spots would be clustered around the macula rather than the bifurcations of the retinal arterioles and dry AMD does not cause acute visual impairment.

B) INCORRECT:

Granulomatous inflammation of the ophthalmic artery is seen in giant cell arteritis (GCA). This condition may cause anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION), which can manifest with monocular amaurosis fugax. However, patients with GCA usually have other symptoms as well (e.g., constitutional symptoms, jaw claudication, headache) and, most importantly, an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Furthermore, AION due to GCA typically manifests with papilledema on fundoscopic examination.

C) CORRECT:

Carotid artery stenosis (CAS) can manifest with monocular amaurosis fugax due to retinal ischemia, caused by stenosis-induced hypoperfusion, thrombosis, or microemboli. This patient has several risk factors for atherosclerosis (hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus, smoking), and fundoscopic examination revealed cholesterol crystal emboli, which most commonly originate from carotid artery atheromas.

Workup for patients with amaurosis fugax generally includes carotid duplex ultrasound to screen for CAS. Carotid revascularization is indicated for patients with symptomatic (e.g., those with amaurosis fugax), severe CAS, and should be considered for patients with symptomatic, moderate CAS, and asymptomatic patients with severe CAS.

D) INCORRECT:

Thrombotic occlusion of the retinal vein (i.e., central retinal vein occlusion) typically leads to a sudden, monocular loss of vision. However, vision loss in central retinal vein occlusion usually does not resolve spontaneously. Furthermore, this condition manifests with massive retinal hemorrhages, dilated tortuous retinal veins, macular edema, and papilledema on fundoscopic examination, none of which is seen here.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of the right eye of a 76-year-old patient

Flame-shaped retinal hemorrhage is visible in all four quadrants (example indicated by green outline). The tortuous veins (green arrows) are markedly dilated and there is papilledema with loss of sharp demarcation of the optic disc (green overlay).

These findings are typical for a central retinal vein occlusion.

E) INCORRECT:

Stasis of blood in the atrium, which occurs in patients with atrial fibrillation (Afib), increases the risk of atrial thrombus formation and arterial thromboembolism. Transient embolic occlusion of the central retinal artery would cause amaurosis fugax. However, this patient does not have an irregular pulse to suggest Afib, and thromboemboli, which are composed of platelets and fibrin, have a white-gray, pale, and nonrefractile appearance on fundoscopy.
questions.hint: This patient presents with painless, monocular amaurosis fugax (i.e., sudden transient vision loss). Hollenhorst plaques (bright, yellow, refractile bodies at the bifurcations of the retinal arterioles) on fundoscopy are caused by cholesterol crystal embolization.

questions.text: An 81-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of left-sided visual loss that started 1 hour ago. He describes initially seeing jagged edges, which was followed by abrupt, complete loss of central vision in the left eye. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Blood pressure is 145/89 mm Hg. A photograph of the fundoscopic findings is shown. Which of the following tests is most likely to confirm this patient's underlying condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased glycated hemoglobin concentrations are seen in patients with poorly controlled diabetes mellitus. This patient has a history of diabetes and is therefore at risk of diabetic retinopathy, a condition that can cause visual impairment and blindness. However, vision loss in diabetic retinopathy is typically bilateral and occurs over the course of many years, as opposed to the abrupt, unilateral vision loss seen in this patient. Direct fundoscopy in a patient with diabetic retinopathy shows microaneurysms, hard exudates, and macular edema (nonproliferative) or retinal neovascularization and vitreous hemorrhage (proliferative).

B) CORRECT:

Carotid artery duplex ultrasonography can be used to evaluate for carotid atherosclerosis, a condition that increases the risk of thromboembolism due to rupture of atherosclerotic plaques, which is the most common cause of central retinal artery occlusion. This patient has several atherosclerotic risk factors, including advanced age, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus, which make thromboembolism secondary to carotid artery atherosclerosis the most likely cause of his symptoms.
Image Description:

Left: lateral view of the right eye in longitudinal (sagittal) section. Depiction of an embolism in the central retinal artery causing retinal ischemia.

Right: fundus photography of the right eye. Diffuse retinal ischemia causes edema in the inner retinal layers, manifesting as a gray-white discoloration of the retina (most markedly around the fovea; dotted circle). The fovea centralis, where the inner retinal layers are moved to the side, is not affected by edema. The underlying, well-vascularized choroid shines through, appearing as a cherry-red spot.

C) INCORRECT:

Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) is a nonspecific inflammatory marker that can be increased in cases of infection, inflammation, or malignancy. Temporal arteritis can cause significant elevation in ESR and is a rare etiology of central retinal artery occlusion, the most likely diagnosis in this patient. However, he lacks other symptoms of temporal arteritis (e.g., headache, jaw claudication, constitutional symptoms). Moreover, a temporal artery biopsy, not ESR, is the gold standard for the diagnosis of temporal arteritis.

D) INCORRECT:

A CD4+ T cell count can be used to track the prognosis in patients diagnosed with or suspected of having HIV. Patients with a low CD4 count are more susceptible to cytomegalovirus, which can cause retinitis and vision loss. However, CMV retinitis causes progressive loss of vision over days as opposed to the abrupt onset seen in this patient's case. Direct fundoscopy in a patient with CMV retinitis shows retinal hemorrhages and cotton wool spots.

E) INCORRECT:

An optic tonometer is used to measure intraocular pressure (IOP). Increased IOP is seen in patients with glaucoma and patients with increased intracranial pressure (ICP). Both of these conditions can lead to visual impairment. In particular, acute, closed-angle glaucoma can cause sudden-onset visual loss. However, it is typically painful and associated with headache and vomiting, none of which is seen in this patient. Direct fundoscopy in patients with increased ICP shows papilledema.
questions.hint: The fundoscopy shows a pale retina with a cherry red spot at the fovea. Together with sudden, painless, transient monocular vision, this finding is concerning for central retinal artery occlusion. Causes include embolism (most common), thrombosis, vasculitis, and fibromuscular dysplasia.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of sudden, painless loss of vision in her right eye that occurred 30 minutes ago. She has coronary artery disease, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Examination shows no perception of light in the right eye. Direct pupillary reflex is present in the left eye but absent in the right eye. Intraocular pressure is normal in both eyes. Fundoscopic examination of the right eye shows a pale, white retina with a bright red area within the macula. The optic disc appears normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypertension, diabetes, and atherosclerosis are all risk factors for ischemic central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO). It may manifest with sudden, painless loss of vision and a relative afferent pupillary defect as well as severe edema of the macula and optic disc. However, fundoscopy would reveal focal retinal hemorrhage instead of a white, pale retina. The most common form of CRVO is nonischemic and results in a decrease in visual acuity over the course of a few days instead of sudden loss of vision seen here.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of a right eye

Multiple punctual hemorrhages in every quadrant of the retina and flame-shaped hemorrhages in the peripapillary and perivascular region are present (examples marked by blue overlay), as are markedly dilated tortuous veins (example framed by white lines) and mild disk edema (blurry margin of the disc marked by dashed blue line, sharply demarcated margin marked by blue line).

This is the classic appearance of central retinal vein occlusion.

M: Macula

B) INCORRECT:

Both hypertension and diabetes mellitus are risk factors for retinal detachment. Patients with extensive retinal detachment or retinal detachment involving the macula would also present with sudden, painless loss of vision, and an afferent pupillary defect. However, fundoscopy would reveal a gray, detached, freely floating retina. Retinal pallor and a cherry red spot within the macula suggest a different diagnosis.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of the left eye

Fibrovascular proliferation (green overlay) obscures the optic disc (dashed circle) and can be seen extending along the retinal vasculature in fibrovascular strands. This has resulted in tractional retinal detachment (blue overlay). Multiple retinal hemorrhages can also be seen (arrowheads).

These findings are characteristic of severe proliferative diabetic retinopathy.

M: macula; N: nasal; T: temporal

C) CORRECT:

The patient has multiple risk factors for retinal artery disease, including diabetes, hypertension, and atherosclerosis. Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) is characterized by sudden, painless loss of vision and an afferent pupillary defect. Ophthalmoscopy findings of CRAO include retinal pallor and a cherry-red spot in the foveal region. Narrow retinal vessels with a cattle-truck appearance are another classic finding of retinal artery occlusion.

Retinal artery occlusion is an ophthalmologic emergency.
Image Description:

Left: lateral view of the right eye in longitudinal (sagittal) section. Depiction of an embolism in the central retinal artery causing retinal ischemia.

Right: fundus photography of the right eye. Diffuse retinal ischemia causes edema in the inner retinal layers, manifesting as a gray-white discoloration of the retina (most markedly around the fovea; dotted circle). The fovea centralis, where the inner retinal layers are moved to the side, is not affected by edema. The underlying, well-vascularized choroid shines through, appearing as a cherry-red spot.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with acute angle closure glaucoma may present with sudden loss of vision, and an absent or sluggish direct pupillary reflex. However, the loss of vision in the case of acute angle closure glaucoma is always associated with severe pain and increased intraocular pressure (> 21 mm Hg), as opposed to the normal intraocular pressure in this patient. The indirect pupillary reflex, which is normal in this patient, would also be impaired. Injection and chemosis of the conjunctiva, as well as trigeminal autonomic symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and lacrimation, which are frequently present in acute angle closure glaucoma, are absent in this patient. On fundoscopy, the optic disc would appear edematous or hyperemic, in contrast to the normal optic disc in this patient.
Image Description:

Slit-lamp photograph of anterior eye segment

Prominent blood vessels are visible on the sclera and conjunctiva (mixed injection). The pupil is medium wide and its shape is slightly irregular. Iris details appear blurred due to corneal endothelial decompensation, leading to corneal edema.

E) INCORRECT:

Anterior ischemic optic neuropathy may also present with sudden, painless loss of vision. However, fundoscopy would reveal a hyperemic or edematous optic disc and possibly splinter hemorrhages within the optic disc, as opposed to a normal optic disc seen in this patient. Retinal pallor and a cherry red spot within the macula suggest a different diagnosis.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of a right eye

The optic disc (dashed circle) shows blurred margins and radial bleedings (arrowheads). The retinal veins are dilated and tortuous (examples indicated by white lines). In addition, the macula (M) shows pigment alterations (blue overlay).

This is the typical appearance of papilledema, in this case caused by NAION. Papilledema can also be caused by arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AAION), inflammatory processes, or elevated intracranial pressure.

Hatched overlay: artifacts
questions.hint: Indirect pupillary reflex will likely be absent in the left (not right!) eye, which would be consistent with retinal or optic nerve damage.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 90-minute history of vision loss in his left eye that developed suddenly while he was watching television. He has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and poorly controlled type 2 diabetes. He has no eye pain, headache, or other symptoms. A dilated fundoscopic examination of the left eye shows papilledema, diffuse flame-shaped hemorrhages, and cotton-wool spots. A photograph of the fundoscopic findings is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) also causes sudden painless vision loss. However, typical findings of CRAO include a gray-white discoloration of the entire retina, narrowing of retinal vessels, cherry-red spot in the fovea, and retinal emboli. Retinal hemorrhages are uncommon in this type of occlusion. Evaluation for an embolic source is appropriate in patients with CRAO.
Image Description:

The image shows the typical findings of retinal whitening with a cherry-red spot in the fovea (arrow) due to the preserved underlying choroidal circulation. There is also constriction of the arteriole and venule with segmentation (arrowhead).

B) CORRECT:

Acute unilateral vision loss in combination with a retinal examination showing papilledema, diffuse flame-shaped hemorrhages, and cotton-wool spots is most consistent with a diagnosis of central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO). Risk factors for CRVO include atherosclerosis, hypertension, glaucoma, and hypercoagulable states. Patients with CRVO should be followed closely for the development of complications associated with neovascularization, such as neovascular glaucoma.

Key learning point: Sudden painless unilateral vision loss and findings of diffuse retinal hemorrhages extending to the periphery and dilated, tortuous veins on retinal examination are indicative of central retinal vein occlusion.

C) INCORRECT:

Arteritic ischemic optic neuropathy from giant-cell arteritis can cause acute painless vision loss, but it only affects the optic nerve and does not cause diffuse retinal findings. It is often associated with headache, scalp tenderness, and jaw claudication.

D) INCORRECT:

Diabetes does not generally cause acute vision loss, except in cases of advanced proliferative diabetic retinopathy. Diabetes can be associated with retinal hemorrhages, but they are usually smaller “dot-blot” hemorrhages that are bilateral and localized to the posterior pole.

E) INCORRECT:

Macular degeneration is generally a slow progressive process and affects only the macula, not the entire retina.

questions.text:
An 82-year-old man presents with a sudden, painless loss of vision in his right eye lasting less than one minute. He describes it as a dark shade descending over his visual field, which fully resolved spontaneously. He has a 20-year history of diabetes mellitus. He has no headache or neurological deficits. Fundoscopy and basic neurologic exam are normal.

Blood pressure
160/90 mm Hg

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Migraine aura usually presents with positive visual phenomena, such as shimmering lights or zigzag patterns, rather than a sudden dark shade. It is more common in younger patients and often follows with headache, nausea, or photophobia, none of which are present here.

B) INCORRECT:

Retinal detachment typically causes persistent vision loss, often with floaters or flashes, and does not resolve spontaneously within minutes. The transient nature of vision loss and normal fundoscopic findings suggest a vascular or embolic event rather than a structural retinal abnormality.

C) CORRECT:

Amaurosis fugax manifests as transient, monocular vision loss, often described as a dark curtain descending over the visual field. This condition results from brief occlusion of the retinal artery, typically due to emboli from atherosclerotic plaques. It is common in elderly individuals with risk factors such as diabetes mellitus and hypertension. The episode's short duration, complete spontaneous resolution, and normal fundoscopic examination align with transient retinal ischemia, which does not cause permanent visual deficits. Understanding these features is crucial for recognizing the underlying vasculopathy and its implications for cerebrovascular health.

Key learning point: Sudden, temporary loss of vision in one eye that resolves spontaneously is characteristic of a transient ischemic attack, specifically amaurosis fugax, and is often associated with vascular risk factors such as diabetes mellitus.

D) INCORRECT:

Vitreous hemorrhage causes sustained vision loss until the hemorrhage clears, not a transient event. It typically alters fundus appearance, obscuring retinal details. The brief vision loss and normal fundoscopic findings argue against this diagnosis.

questions.text: You are seeing a 72-year-old man in the emergency department 45 minutes after he experienced a sudden, painless, transient loss of vision in his right eye that lasted for 5 minutes. His medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has a 48-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily. Pulse is 72/min and regular. Fundoscopic examination of the right eye reveals Hollenhorst plaques. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 10 mm/h (0–10). ECG shows regular sinus rhythm. Which one of the following is the most likely explanation for his loss of vision?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Granulomatous inflammation of the ophthalmic artery is seen in giant cell arteritis (GCA). This condition may cause anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION), which can manifest with monocular amaurosis fugax. However, patients with GCA usually have other symptoms as well (e.g., constitutional symptoms, jaw claudication, headache) and, most importantly, an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Furthermore, AION due to GCA typically manifests with papilledema on fundoscopic examination.

B) INCORRECT:

Stasis of blood in the atrium, which occurs in patients with atrial fibrillation (Afib), increases the risk of atrial thrombus formation and arterial thromboembolism. Transient embolic occlusion of the central retinal artery would cause amaurosis fugax. However, this patient does not have an irregular pulse to suggest Afib, and thromboemboli, which are composed of platelets and fibrin, have a white-gray, pale, and nonrefractile appearance on fundoscopy.

C) INCORRECT:

Dry age-related macular degeneration (AMD) causes the formation of drusen, which are yellow retinal spots that can have a refractile appearance. However, these spots would be clustered around the macula rather than the bifurcations of the retinal arterioles and dry AMD does not cause acute visual impairment.

D) CORRECT:

Carotid artery stenosis (CAS) can manifest with monocular amaurosis fugax due to retinal ischemia, caused by stenosis-induced hypoperfusion, thrombosis, or microemboli. This patient has several risk factors for atherosclerosis (hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus, smoking), and fundoscopic examination revealed cholesterol crystal emboli, which most commonly originate from carotid artery atheromas.

Workup for patients with amaurosis fugax generally includes carotid duplex ultrasound to screen for CAS. Carotid revascularization is indicated for patients with symptomatic (e.g., those with amaurosis fugax), severe CAS, and should be considered for patients with symptomatic, moderate CAS, and asymptomatic patients with severe CAS.

Key learning point: Transient monocular vision loss with Hollenhorst plaques is most often caused by retinal emboli from internal carotid artery stenosis due to atherosclerosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Thrombotic occlusion of the retinal vein (i.e., central retinal vein occlusion) typically leads to a sudden, monocular loss of vision. However, vision loss in central retinal vein occlusion usually does not resolve spontaneously. Furthermore, this condition manifests with massive retinal hemorrhages, dilated tortuous retinal veins, macular edema, and papilledema on fundoscopic examination, none of which is seen here.
questions.hint: This patient presents with painless, monocular amaurosis fugax (i.e., sudden transient vision loss). Hollenhorst plaques (bright, yellow, refractile bodies at the bifurcations of the retinal arterioles) on fundoscopy are caused by cholesterol crystal embolization.

questions.text: You are seeing a 60-year-old woman who is brought to the emergency department because of sudden, painless loss of vision in her right eye that began 30 minutes ago. Her medical history includes coronary artery disease, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. On examination, there is no perception of light in the right eye. The direct pupillary reflex is present in the left eye but absent in the right eye. Intraocular pressure is normal in both eyes. Fundoscopic examination of the right eye reveals a pale, white retina with a bright red area within the macula. The optic disc appears normal. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anterior ischemic optic neuropathy may also present with sudden, painless loss of vision. However, fundoscopy would reveal a hyperemic or edematous optic disc and possibly splinter hemorrhages within the optic disc, as opposed to a normal optic disc seen in this patient. Retinal pallor and a cherry red spot within the macula suggest a different diagnosis.

B) CORRECT:

The patient has multiple risk factors for retinal artery disease, including diabetes, hypertension, and atherosclerosis. Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) is characterized by sudden, painless loss of vision and an afferent pupillary defect. Ophthalmoscopy findings of CRAO include retinal pallor and a cherry-red spot in the foveal region. Narrow retinal vessels with a cattle-truck appearance are another classic finding of retinal artery occlusion.

Retinal artery occlusion is an ophthalmologic emergency.

Key learning point: Central retinal artery occlusion presents as sudden, painless vision loss with a pale retina and a cherry-red spot on fundoscopic exam, and is an ophthalmologic emergency.
Image Description:

Left: lateral view of the right eye in longitudinal (sagittal) section. Depiction of an embolism in the central retinal artery causing retinal ischemia.

Right: fundus photography of the right eye. Diffuse retinal ischemia causes edema in the inner retinal layers, manifesting as a gray-white discoloration of the retina (most markedly around the fovea; dotted circle). The fovea centralis, where the inner retinal layers are moved to the side, is not affected by edema. The underlying, well-vascularized choroid shines through, appearing as a cherry-red spot.

C) INCORRECT:

Both hypertension and diabetes mellitus are risk factors for retinal detachment. Patients with extensive retinal detachment or retinal detachment involving the macula would also present with sudden, painless loss of vision, and an afferent pupillary defect. However, fundoscopy would reveal a gray, detached, freely floating retina. Retinal pallor and a cherry red spot within the macula suggest a different diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypertension, diabetes, and atherosclerosis are all risk factors for ischemic central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO). It may manifest with sudden, painless loss of vision and a relative afferent pupillary defect as well as severe edema of the macula and optic disc. However, fundoscopy would reveal focal retinal hemorrhage instead of a white, pale retina. The most common form of CRVO is nonischemic and results in a decrease in visual acuity over the course of a few days instead of sudden loss of vision seen here.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with acute angle closure glaucoma may present with sudden loss of vision, and an absent or sluggish direct pupillary reflex. However, the loss of vision in the case of acute angle closure glaucoma is always associated with severe pain and increased intraocular pressure (> 21 mm Hg), as opposed to the normal intraocular pressure in this patient. The indirect pupillary reflex, which is normal in this patient, would also be impaired. Injection and chemosis of the conjunctiva, as well as trigeminal autonomic symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and lacrimation, which are frequently present in acute angle closure glaucoma, are absent in this patient. On fundoscopy, the optic disc would appear edematous or hyperemic, in contrast to the normal optic disc in this patient.
questions.hint: Indirect pupillary reflex will likely be absent in the left (not right!) eye, which would be consistent with retinal or optic nerve damage.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man presents to the emergency department with sudden vision loss in his left eye that began 90 minutes ago while he was watching television. He has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and poorly controlled type 2 diabetes. He does not report eye pain, headache, or other symptoms. On dilated fundoscopic examination of the left eye, you observe papilledema, diffuse flame-shaped hemorrhages, and cotton-wool spots. A photograph of the fundoscopic findings is provided. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diabetes does not generally cause acute vision loss, except in cases of advanced proliferative diabetic retinopathy. Diabetes can be associated with retinal hemorrhages, but they are usually smaller “dot-blot” hemorrhages that are bilateral and localized to the posterior pole.

B) INCORRECT:

Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) also causes sudden painless vision loss. However, typical findings of CRAO include a gray-white discoloration of the entire retina, narrowing of retinal vessels, cherry-red spot in the fovea, and retinal emboli. Retinal hemorrhages are uncommon in this type of occlusion. Evaluation for an embolic source is appropriate in patients with CRAO.

C) CORRECT:

Acute unilateral vision loss in combination with a retinal examination showing papilledema, diffuse flame-shaped hemorrhages, and cotton-wool spots is most consistent with a diagnosis of central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO). Risk factors for CRVO include atherosclerosis, hypertension, glaucoma, and hypercoagulable states. Patients with CRVO should be followed closely for the development of complications associated with neovascularization, such as neovascular glaucoma.

Key learning point: Sudden painless unilateral vision loss and findings of diffuse retinal hemorrhages extending to the periphery and dilated, tortuous veins on retinal examination are indicative of central retinal vein occlusion.

D) INCORRECT:

Arteritic ischemic optic neuropathy from giant-cell arteritis can cause acute painless vision loss, but it only affects the optic nerve and does not cause diffuse retinal findings. It is often associated with headache, scalp tenderness, and jaw claudication.

E) INCORRECT:

Macular degeneration is generally a slow progressive process and affects only the macula, not the entire retina.

questions.text: An 81-year-old man presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of left-sided visual loss that began 1 hour ago. He reports initially seeing jagged edges, followed by abrupt, complete loss of central vision in the left eye. His medical history includes hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Blood pressure is 145/89 mm Hg. A photograph of the fundoscopic findings is provided. Which one of the following tests is most likely to confirm the underlying condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) is a nonspecific inflammatory marker that can be increased in cases of infection, inflammation, or malignancy. Temporal arteritis can cause significant elevation in ESR and is a rare etiology of central retinal artery occlusion, the most likely diagnosis in this patient. However, he lacks other symptoms of temporal arteritis (e.g., headache, jaw claudication, constitutional symptoms). Moreover, a temporal artery biopsy, not ESR, is the gold standard for the diagnosis of temporal arteritis.

B) INCORRECT:

A CD4+ T cell count can be used to track the prognosis in patients diagnosed with or suspected of having HIV. Patients with a low CD4 count are more susceptible to cytomegalovirus, which can cause retinitis and vision loss. However, CMV retinitis causes progressive loss of vision over days as opposed to the abrupt onset seen in this patient's case. Direct fundoscopy in a patient with CMV retinitis shows retinal hemorrhages and cotton wool spots.

C) INCORRECT:

An optic tonometer is used to measure intraocular pressure (IOP). Increased IOP is seen in patients with glaucoma and patients with increased intracranial pressure (ICP). Both of these conditions can lead to visual impairment. In particular, acute, closed-angle glaucoma can cause sudden-onset visual loss. However, it is typically painful and associated with headache and vomiting, none of which is seen in this patient. Direct fundoscopy in patients with increased ICP shows papilledema.

D) CORRECT:

Carotid artery duplex ultrasonography can be used to evaluate for carotid atherosclerosis, a condition that increases the risk of thromboembolism due to rupture of atherosclerotic plaques, which is the most common cause of central retinal artery occlusion. This patient has several atherosclerotic risk factors, including advanced age, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus, which make thromboembolism secondary to carotid artery atherosclerosis the most likely cause of his symptoms.

Key learning point: Carotid artery atherosclerosis is the most common cause of central retinal artery occlusion, and carotid duplex ultrasonography is the key diagnostic test to confirm this underlying etiology.
Image Description:

Left: lateral view of the right eye in longitudinal (sagittal) section. Depiction of an embolism in the central retinal artery causing retinal ischemia.

Right: fundus photography of the right eye. Diffuse retinal ischemia causes edema in the inner retinal layers, manifesting as a gray-white discoloration of the retina (most markedly around the fovea; dotted circle). The fovea centralis, where the inner retinal layers are moved to the side, is not affected by edema. The underlying, well-vascularized choroid shines through, appearing as a cherry-red spot.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased glycated hemoglobin concentrations are seen in patients with poorly controlled diabetes mellitus. This patient has a history of diabetes and is therefore at risk of diabetic retinopathy, a condition that can cause visual impairment and blindness. However, vision loss in diabetic retinopathy is typically bilateral and occurs over the course of many years, as opposed to the abrupt, unilateral vision loss seen in this patient. Direct fundoscopy in a patient with diabetic retinopathy shows microaneurysms, hard exudates, and macular edema (nonproliferative) or retinal neovascularization and vitreous hemorrhage (proliferative).
questions.hint: The fundoscopy shows a pale retina with a cherry red spot at the fovea. Together with sudden, painless, transient monocular vision, this finding is concerning for central retinal artery occlusion. Causes include embolism (most common), thrombosis, vasculitis, and fibromuscular dysplasia.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman presents with sudden, painless vision loss in her left eye that began 3 hours ago. Her history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and recent episodes of transient monocular vision loss in the same eye. Visual acuity is 20/400 in the left eye and 20/20 in the right eye. A relative afferent pupillary defect is present in the left eye. Fundoscopic examination appears normal. What is the most appropriate immediate management?

choices.text: Perform urgent CT angiography of the head and neck
Initiate emergency ophthalmology and stroke evaluation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Carotid imaging helps identify an embolic source but should not delay another emergent evaluation.

B) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids are indicated for arteritic ischemic optic neuropathy from giant cell arteritis, which typically presents with jaw claudication, scalp tenderness, or elevated inflammatory markers. This patient’s risk factors and history of transient monocular blindness suggest another cause.

C) INCORRECT:

Vascular imaging may follow, but another initial management step takes precedence.

D) INCORRECT:

Antiplatelet therapy is used for secondary prevention once the cause is identified. Another immediate step takes precedence.

E) CORRECT:

Correct –Acute painless monocular vision loss may represent central retinal artery occlusion, an ocular form of ischemic stroke. Immediate ophthalmologic assessment and concurrent stroke pathway activation are required for potential reperfusion and systemic workup.
